Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Brent Nelson is "Free Probability and Deformation/Rigidity Theory for Type III von Neumann Algebras." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California, Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Dan-Virgil Voiculescu.

Performance_Institution.Name: The Department of Mathematics at Berkeley

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI produced a series of papers applying and extending the free transport results of Guionnet and Shlyahktenko. These papers, co-authored with Q. Zeng and M. Hartglass provide new (trace-preserving) isomorphism results for C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras.

In a collaboration with M. Fathi, the PI also generalized the notion of Stein kernels and Stein discrepancy from probability theory to the non-commutative setting. This allowed them to produce a strict improvement of Biane and Speicher's so-called free log-Sobolev inequality. From this improvement, one can easily estimate how quickly the free entropy converges along a free central limiting sequence.

The PI also studied the non-tracial analogue of free Fisher information. This quantity describes how well-behaved non-commutative random variables are under a certain differential calclulus.  The PI showed that if this behavior is good enough, then the von Neumann algebra these variables generate will have certain nice properties; namely, it will be a full factor equipped with a state whose centralizer is also a factor.

In the Spring of 2016, the PI co-organized a five day workshop at UC Berkeley on operator algebras, free probability, and random matrix theory. The meeting brought together 30 researchers from the US, Canada, Europe, and Japan. The PI also co-organzied a similar three day workshop at UC Berkeley in the Fall of 2017, and an AMS Special Session at the 2018 Joint Mathematics Meetings in San Diego.

The PI mentored four UC Berkeley graduate students as they applied for the NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship, providing feedback on their application materials for this fellowship as well as for general postdoctoral positions. The PI also co-mentored a UC Berkeley undergraduate as he wrote his honors thesis on free probability.

The PI also engaged in public outreach by speaking at UC Berkeley's Cal Day in 2017 and 2018. In Spring 2018, the PI gave a talk on random matrix theory in a seminar organized by the Mathematics Undergraduate Student Association. The same organization awarded the PI a Distinguished Teaching Award in the Spring of 2018.
